Articles.Content:
A while back they introduced Kerb-net and anomalies, but I feel the implementation could be vastly improved.

#1) When an anomaly is detected, it should only display a "?" if is still unknown. Its just clutter to show every ground station, and already found anomaly. I suggest that if an anomaly is Known, a "K" should be displayed instead of a "?". Known anomalies would be the space center (and alternate launch sites + ground stations if enabled), and those anomalies which have already triggered the "World's First" rewards - clearly KSP is already tracking which ones are known and which aren't

#2) When discovered, an icon should be added to the map, the current method of spamming waypoints is less than ideal.

#3) Increase detection chance to 100%. Currently starting with the early probes that have a 6% chance per day of detecting an anomaly requires that you fly over an area (and click refresh) 11 times (once per game-day, clicking multiple times per game-day is no help) to have a 50% chance of detecting it. This is a tedious click fest. Instead the higher level probe cores should give greater precision. Suppose early probe cores locate the anomaly to somewhere within 20km, and higher level ones will locate it to within 500m... or something like that. Perhaps modified by the FOV, and orbital height, so if you launch an early probe into a low orbit that passes over the anomaly detected from high orbit, you can refine its position

#4) Give rewards once the tech tree is finished. AFAIK, every body with a solid surface has one of these. Finding the ones on Kerbin, Mun, and Minmus when you have only 1000 science point tech left to unlock makes them rather large rewards... But suppose you finish the tech tree before arriving at duna, and locate one there... rewards: nothing. I would propose that after the tech tree is complete, you gain 1000 science points, modified by whatever strategies you have in place (such as science to funding, or science to Rep).

Without changes, I think this feature will continue to be neglected by the playerbase because its simply far too much babysitting of a probe and clicking, to wait for an RNG to show you an anomaly (that you then have to sort out if its one that you already found), just to unlock one tech, when getting science from biomes on Mun and Minmus is less of a grind and more interesting.

I would prefer a more ScanSat system in place - if you leave a probe core to scan the surface, it eventually compiles a rough map of anomalies. Better probe cores would pinpoint anomaly locations to more accurate places on the map. The map would also show the biome divisions, and can be called up at anytime during flight.

Yes, I would prefer it to be automated as well, but I thought that might be too much to ask.

We seem to be in agreement on the idea of " Better probe cores would pinpoint anomaly locations to more accurate places on the map "

100% to this. Kerbnet is great for finding good mining sites but its not as if I'm just circling around with it open and my finger hovering over the waypoint button. Also agreed on removing the chance of discovery and adding automatic flagging. I'd love to see a more general de-clickifying of the science system but this is a great place to start. 

I'm not sure how the accuracy idea would represent itself but I'm into the concept. Would it be like a fuzzy dot? Somehow you couldn't count on it being in the center? Another way to modulate discovery strength would be to give larger cores a larger scan radius, but that might present its own problems. 

Agreed on giving them rewards as well, although I feel like you should have to visit them to get the rewards (were you already implying this?). This probably would require some legwork but would be so worth it. 

Another thing I'd love as a part of this would be biome overlays in map mode. It's possible in the debug menu, just needs some visual cleanup. If they didn't want to go full SCANsat these could easily be unlocked using the survey scanner.

Edited April 16, 2019 by Pthigrivi

7 hours ago, Pthigrivi said:

I'm not sure how the accuracy idea would represent itself but I'm into the concept. Would it be like a fuzzy dot? Somehow you couldn't count on it being in the center?

As I envision it, a probe would have an accuracy rating. When an anomaly is detected, it would roll an RNG twice: once for a direction (in degrees), and once for a distance (from 0-0.5 km). So say it rolls 91 degrees and 0.35 km: For a probe with an accuracy rating of 1, the waypoint would actually be placed 350 meters due east (91 degrees compass heading) of the actual anomaly.

For an early probe with an accuracy rating of 0.1, the distance would be divided by the accuracy rating: 350 meters / 0.1 = 3.5 km: A really bad probe with an accuracy rating of 0.05 would be off by 7km... and could be off by as much as 10km, or "right on the money" depending on the RNG roll. So the worst Early probe would give you a roughly 10km search radius for the anomaly, and a late probe drops this down to 500 meters (perhaps 500 meters should be changed to 1 km... numbers open to tweaking).

I could further see modifying this by orbital height as a % of the low/high space boundary:

https://wiki.kerbalspaceprogram.com/wiki/Science#Celestial_body_multipliers

So for kerbin, that border is 250km. A probe at 250km would have its error multiplied by 250/250 = 1... Whereas a probe orbiting at 500 km would have its margin of error doubled (500/250), and a probe that detects the anomaly from a low-ish orbit of 125 km would have its error margin halved... so using the numbers above, an early probe detecting an anomaly from an 80km orbit would have a maximum error of 80/250* 0.5km /0.05 = 3.2 km. I would give such an early probe a fairly narrow view range.

So early on, you could put a probe into high orbit to view the entire surface of kerbin at once (lets say with its FOV, that happens at 500km), and your maximum error is 20km, which could make a search from the surface quite hard.... so you launch a 2nd probe to pass over that area from low orbit, and get a pretty good fix on the location.

Quote

Agreed on giving them rewards as well, although I feel like you should have to visit them to get the rewards (were you already implying this?). This probably would require some legwork but would be so worth it. 

Yes, in my mind, getting a "?" from orbit is not finding the anomaly, its just getting the general vicinity... you would actually have to visit it to get a reward (as you do now)... the only change here is that they still give rewards after the tech tree is finished.

The Green Monoliths are useful in low-science careers - They unlock tech tree nodes for free. This should further incentivised and made easier to execute.

I've abused this several times now - i've picked nodes from visiting the green monoliths on the Mun, Minmus, Duna, Ike, Gilly, Dres and Bop.

Well, in my custom system, Mun goes where Minmus normally is, and Minmus goes way out into solar orbit in an orbit similar to dres'

So my grinding capability is diminished

5 hours ago, KerikBalm said:

Yes, in my mind, getting a "?" from orbit is not finding the anomaly, its just getting the general vicinity... you would actually have to visit it to get a reward (as you do now)... the only change here is that they still give rewards after the tech tree is finished.

Gotcha gotcha. We're on the same page here. Just misunderstood what you meant by "find". Though, tbh, if we're making these significantly easier to find I feel like the rewards would want to be rejiggered, possibly to just a straight science/funds/rep bonus with planetary multipliers like biomes have so they scale and can't be easily abused. While I really wish the anomaly system better integrated it should really just be a bonus path to success, and not turn the KSP into the anomaly game.

I'd also love to see this system expanded to include a host of more scientific feeling anomalies, but again thats probably beyond the scope of this suggestion.

Edited April 16, 2019 by Pthigrivi

if we're making these significantly easier to find I feel like the rewards would want to be rejiggered, possibly to just a straight science/funds/rep bonus with planetary multipliers like biomes have so they scale and can't be easily abused. 

Well, I'd say less "grindy". As it is now its not too hard, just grindy with button spam. I think "difficulty" could be adjusted by tweaking the numbers as to the size of the search radius. Then its a matter of planning to put a low flying bird (low if in space, high if a plane) over the search area. To me that's more interesting than just remembering to click the kerbneb button every day.

Totally. I just thinking in terms of weighting, like how much player effort it takes to get one reward vs another will drive the way we play. The value of being able to unlock a node depends on where you currently are on the tech tree rather than how hard to reach a given anomaly is. That isn't really an issue now because so few people bother given the hoops you've got to jump through to find them, but if we make them easier to find that calculus changes. Im just suggesting we follow through on your assertion that they should carry value after the tech tree is complete and just make them always pay out in some combination of science, rep and/or funds rather than tech unlocks. Its simpler to understand, and like I said you could weight them so anomalies right close to KSC are worth less and ones on Tylo are worth much more.
